title: Are only blue-eyed blondes considered white? - Quora

response.answer_text: It really depends what country you’re from. Race is a cultural construct, and each culture has its own definitions of “white”. Indians think light skin is better than dark skin, though it’s a continuum over there. I hear that Persians have a similar complex. Italians think anyone who has hair lighter than dark brown is “bionda” (blonde). Americans think if you’re from a Spanish-speaking country, you are “not white”, even though Spain is Western European. They made up the “race” of “Hispanic” just so they could express their racism towards anyone of Latin origin. My ex-wife is Swedish, but with dark hair and green eyes. She was often stopped by racist skinheads in Sweden demanding to know her origin, since she wasn’t blonde enough to be a “real Swede”. Maybe the original poster of this question is from around there.

I have only ever seen questions like this from the US. It is very odd because they have a lot of ancestry from Britain and Ireland which are not blonde majority countries at all. Most people are brown-haired, from light to dark and only half of Brits are blue-eyed. So…you are saying British and Irish people aren’t white? The other country a lot of white Americans have descent from is Germany. Although in the north there are many blondes, not so much in the south. And how about within one family, where you might get one blonde sibling and one brunette. Despite having the same parents, would you honestly think one was ‘white’ and one not?

No. I am brunette with hazel eyes and pale, freckled skin. I identify as white. My mom has dirty blonde hair and brown eyes, she identifies as white. My friend has black hair and dark eyes and pale skin, she identifies as white. My dad has red-brown hair and blue eyes, he identifies as white. What people identify as is up to them so if you really want to know what people identify as ask them.

No, white people can have different hair colour black, brown and red and eye colour brown eyes green and hazel, you don't have to be blonde with blue eyes to be white Keira Knighley has brown hair and brown eyes and she's white
